question: A.1 [1.0 point] In a subcritical reactor with Keff of 0.931, a reactivity worth of 1.70 %Δk/k is inserted into the reactor core.  Which ONE of the following is the NEW Keff ?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page  3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page  3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page  3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page  3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  0.017 = (x-0.931)/(x*0.931); 0.017*0.931*x =x-0.931 0.01583x=x-0.931; 0.98417x =0.931; x=0.931/0.98417; x=0.946

question: A.2 [1.0 point] Changes made during the administration of the examination The reactor is critical.  At time t=0, Keff is changed to 1.010.   What is the period of the reactor? Given a prompt neutron lifetime (ℓ*) of 1 x 10 -4 seconds.

answers.feedback: Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4: T=ℓ*/ (K eff – 1) T= 0.0001/0.010=0.01 sec If using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01   ρ = 0.01 For promt, ρ lΤ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec

Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4: T=ℓ*/ (K eff – 1) T= 0.0001/0.010=0.01 sec If using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01   ρ = 0.01 For promt, ρ lΤ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec

Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4: T=ℓ*/ (K eff – 1) T= 0.0001/0.010=0.01 sec If using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01   ρ = 0.01 For promt, ρ lΤ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec

Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4: T=ℓ*/ (K eff – 1) T= 0.0001/0.010=0.01 sec If using equations provided in the equation sheet: ρ = (1.01-1)/1.01   ρ = 0.01 For promt, ρ lΤ = 0.0001/0.01 = 0.01 sec

question: A.3 [1.0 point] The reactor is on a CONSTANT positive period.  Which ONE of the following power changes will take the SHORTEST time to complete?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/T  ––> t= TLn(P/ P0 ) assume constant period = 1 t= Ln(P/ P0 )   ––>  the smallest ratio of P/ P0 is the shortest time to complete; so it is 150kW/100kW.
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/T  ––> t= TLn(P/ P0 ) assume constant period = 1 t= Ln(P/ P0 )   ––>  the smallest ratio of P/ P0 is the shortest time to complete; so it is 150kW/100kW.
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/T  ––> t= TLn(P/ P0 ) assume constant period = 1 t= Ln(P/ P0 )   ––>  the smallest ratio of P/ P0 is the shortest time to complete; so it is 150kW/100kW.
Correct. Reference: P = P0 et/T  ––> t= TLn(P/ P0 ) assume constant period = 1 t= Ln(P/ P0 )   ––>  the smallest ratio of P/ P0 is the shortest time to complete; so it is 150kW/100kW.

question: A.4 [1.0 point]  New question added during the administration of the examination Which ONE of the following isotopes has the highest thermal neutron absorption cross section?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.

question:
A.5 [1.0 point] Given the following Core Reactivity Data during startup:
Control Rod
Total Rod Worth
($) Rod Worth still in the
core (excess) ($)
SAFE Rod
3.50 1.00
SHIM Rod
2.50 0.80
REG Rod 1
1.80 0.50
Total
7.80 2.30
Which ONE of the following would be the Shutdown Margin specified in the Reed Tech Spec?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:  TS 3.1.2 Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth – (Core excess + most active rod worth)          =  $7.8 –(2.3+3.5) =$2.00
Incorrect. Reference:  TS 3.1.2 Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth – (Core excess + most active rod worth)          =  $7.8 –(2.3+3.5) =$2.00
Incorrect. Reference:  TS 3.1.2 Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth – (Core excess + most active rod worth)          =  $7.8 –(2.3+3.5) =$2.00
Incorrect. Reference:  TS 3.1.2 Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth – (Core excess + most active rod worth)          =  $7.8 –(2.3+3.5) =$2.00

question: A.6 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the most correct reason for having an installed neutron source within the core?   An installed neutron source is very important during startup because without of a neutron source...

answers.answer: a. the chain reaction in the reactor core would NOT start
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

answers.answer: b. the startup channel would NEVER indicate neutron population
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

answers.answer: c. the compensating voltage on the source range detector doesn’t work
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

answers.answer: d. the reactor could result in a sudden increase in power if the control rods were pulled out far enough
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

question: A.7 [1.0 point] Two critical reactors at low power are identical, except that Reactor 1 has a beta fraction of 0.0065 and Reactor 2 has a beta fraction of 0.0072.  Which ONE of the following best describes the response if an equal amount of positive reactivity is inserted into both reactors?

answers.answer: a. Period of the Reactor 1 will be longer than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:   Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: b. Period of the Reactor 1 will be shorter than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:   Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: c. The final power in the Reactor 1 will be lower than the final power in the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:   Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: d. The trace (power vs. time) of the Reactor 1 will be identical to the trace of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:   Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

question: A.8 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes the effects of moderator temperature increase on neutron multiplication?

answers.answer: a. Resonance escape probability ↑; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↑
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

answers.answer: b. Resonance escape probability ↓; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↑
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

answers.answer: c. Resonance escape probability ↑; Thermal non-leakage↑; Rod worth ↓
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

answers.answer: d. Resonance escape probability ↓; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↓
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

question: A.9 [1.0 point] In a just critical reactor, the reactor operator immediately inserts a rabbit of $0.50 reactivity worth into the core.  This insertion will cause: Given: T: reactor period, ℓ*: Prompt neutron lifetime; ρ: reactivity insertion; β: beta fraction

answers.answer: a. A sudden drop in delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: b.    A number of prompt neutrons equals to a number of delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: c.    The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime (T=ℓ*/ρ)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: d.    A sudden change of power that equals to the initial power multiplied by β(1- ρ)/ (β -ρ)
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

question: A.10 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is a correct statement of why delayed neutrons enhance the ability to control reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Prompt neutrons can cause fissions in both U-235 and U-238; where as delayed neutrons can only cause fissions in U-235
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

answers.answer: b. The average number of delayed neutrons produced per fission is higher than the  average number of prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energy levels than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron lifetime that allows a reactor to be controlled
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

question: A.11 [1.0 point] TRIGA reactor fuel has a unique feature known as the prompt negative temperature coefficient (PNTC).  Which ONE of the following is the MAJOR contributor of the PNTC?

answers.answer: a. As the fuel heats up, the resonance absorption peaks broaden and increases the likelihood of absorption in U-238 and/or Pu-240.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

answers.answer: b. As the fuel heats up, a moderator temperature increase reduces the non-leakage and resonance escape probability.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

answers.answer: c. As the fuel heats up, fission product poisons (e.g., Xe) increase in concentration within the fuel matrix and add negative reactivity via neutron absorption.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

answers.answer: d. As the fuel heats up, the oscillating hydrogen atoms in the ZrH have more energy than the thermal neutrons, thus they transfers energy to the thermal neutrons, cause the thermal neutron to leave the fuel without fissions.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

question: A.12 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following statements correctly describes thermal neutrons?

answers.answer: a. A neutron that experiences a linear decrease in energy as the temperature of the moderator increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: NRC Standard Question

answers.answer: b. A neutron at resonant epithermal energy levels that causes fissions to occur in U-238.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: NRC Standard Question

answers.answer: c. A neutron that experiences an increase in energy levels after collisions with larger atoms of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: NRC Standard Question

answers.answer: d. A neutron that experiences no net change in energy after several collisions with atoms of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: NRC Standard Question

question: A.13 [1.0 point] Reactor power is increasing by a factor of 10 every minute.  The reactor period is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:  P=Poe t/τ    J = 60 sec/ln(10) = 26.06 sec
Incorrect. Reference:  P=Poe t/τ    J = 60 sec/ln(10) = 26.06 sec
Correct. Reference:  P=Poe t/τ    J = 60 sec/ln(10) = 26.06 sec
Incorrect. Reference:  P=Poe t/τ    J = 60 sec/ln(10) = 26.06 sec

question: A.14 [1.0 point] Given a source strength of 100 neutrons per second (N/sec) and a multiplication factor of 0.75, which ONE of the following is the expected stable neutron count rate?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 100/(1 - .75) = 400
Incorrect. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 100/(1 - .75) = 400
Correct. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 100/(1 - .75) = 400
Incorrect. Reference: CR = S/(1-K)  →  CR = 100/(1 - .75) = 400

question: A.15 [1.0 point] During a reactor startup, the reactor operator calculates that the current core excess is HIGHER than the last startup.  Which ONE of the following reasons could be the cause?

answers.answer: a.  Higher moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:  Standard NRC question.

answers.answer: b.  Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference:  Standard NRC question.

answers.answer: c.  Burnout of a burnable poison
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference:  Standard NRC question.
Incorrect. Reference:  Standard NRC question.

question: A.16 [1.0 point] About two minutes following a reactor scram, the reactor period has stabilized and the power level is decreasing at a CONSTANT rate.  Given that reactor power at time t0 is 9 kW power, what will it be five minutes later?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 9 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 9 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 9 kW = 210 W
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 9 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 9 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 9 kW = 210 W
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 9 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 9 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 9 kW = 210 W
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 9 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 9 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 9 kW = 210 W

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is an example of alpha decay?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1

question: A.18 [1.0 point] Xenon-135 (Xe135) is produced in the reactor by two methods.  One is directly from fission; the other is indirectly from the decay of :

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988,  §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988,  §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988,  §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988,  §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
